meta_description: Explore the Nova Southeastern University&#8217s Museum of Art | Fort Lauderdale. Art exhibitions, Academy art classes for adults & kids, wine tastings, book signings & more. Near Las Olas Blvd
hours_text:
**Museum Gallery Hours:**  
  
Museum galleries will be open daily 11 a.m. – 5 p.m. with extended hours on Thursdays until 8 p.m. and Sundays 12 p.m. - 5 p.m. **CLOSED MONDAYS.**

_Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Years and July 4._

**_December 24 (Christmas Eve),_ the galleries will close at 2 p.m. **

**General Admission Fees:**

Adults (18+) : $10.00  
Seniors (65+), Military: $7.00

Students (13-17) and non-NSU College Students: $5.00 & non-NSU College Students with valid ID: $5.00  
Students (12 and under): FREE

NSU Students, Faculty and Staff: FREE

Museum Members: FREE  
  
Group rates are available for groups of 10 or more by contacting the group sales office at 954-262-0204 or .  
  
_Please note: Ticket pricing may change for special ticketed exhibitions.  
  
The Museum requires visitors to leave backpacks of any size, shopping bags, umbrellas, etc behind the Admissions desk.  
  
Photography, cell phone usage, food or beverages are not permitted in the galleries._

2015 Educator Guide

Directions and Parking

collections_text:
#  Cafe Dolly: Picabia, Schnabel, Willumsen

Julian Schnabel

Large Girl with No Eyes, 2001  
Oil and wax on canvas  
Collection of the Artist  
© 2014 Julian Schnabel / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

**Café Dolly: Picabia, Schnabel, Willumsen**

**October 12, 2014 - February 1, 2015**

Bringing together the work of French artist Francis Picabia (1879–1953), American artist Julian Schnabel (b. 1951), and Danish artist Jens Ferdinand Willumsen (1863–1958) for the first time in the United States, the exhibition Café Dolly: Picabia, Schnabel, Willumsen will be on view at NSU Museum of Art Fort Lauderdale from October 12, 2014 - February 1, 2015. The illuminating exhibition reveals surprising connections between stylistic and painterly concerns that span generations and geography.

Featuring approximately 75 paintings, Café Dolly presents works dating from 1926–1951 by French artist Picabia, whose contributions to the avant-garde Dada and Surrealist movements are widely known, but whose paintings from his later figurative period remain relatively obscure in the United States. The exhibition also includes paintings from the late 1980s to the present by New York artist Julian Schnabel, including works on a collaged surface of broken plates, resin-coated figurative paintings, enormous canvases based on paintings found in thrift stores, and paintings that conflate figuration and abstraction. In addition, the exhibition includes paintings from the late 19th- to mid-20th centu...
